case_name: State of Andhra Pradesh v. Chenchamma

facts.text: Appeal is from the judgment and decree dated December 20, 1955, of the former Andhra Pradesh High Court in Appeal Suit No. 716 of 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated December 20, 1955, of the former Andhra Pradesh High Court in Appeal Suit No. 716 of 1952.

facts.text: Veeranna died on 2.2.1906.

anchor.surface_text: Veeranna  d. 2.2.1906  Atchamma Seshamma  1st wife   2nd wife

facts.text: Pitchayya predeceased Veeranna on 1-9-1905 leaving widow Raghavamma.

anchor.surface_text: Veeranna died in the year 1906 and his second son Pitchayya had predeceased him on 1-9-1905 leaving his widow Raghavamma.

facts.text: Pitchayya allegedly took Venkayya, son of Chimpirayya, in adoption sometime before his death.

anchor.surface_text: It is alleged that sometime before his death, Pitchayya took Venkayya, the son of his brother Chimpirayya in adoption

facts.text: Partition of joint family properties allegedly occurred in or about 1895 between Veeranna and his four sons.

anchor.surface_text: and it is also alleged that in or about the year 1895, there was a partition of the joint family properties between Veeranna and his four sons

facts.text: Venkayya died on May 24, 1938, leaving son Subbarao.

anchor.surface_text: Venkayya died on May 24, 1938, leaving behind a son Subbarao.

facts.text: Chimpirayya died on May 5, 1945.

anchor.surface_text: Chimpirayya died on May 5, 1945 having executed a will dated January 14, 1945

facts.text: Chimpirayya executed a will dated January 14, 1945.

anchor.surface_text: having executed a will dated January 14, 1945 whereunder he gave his properties in equal shares to Subbarao and Kamalamma

facts.text: Subbarao died on July 28, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: Subbarao died on July 28, 1949. Raghavamma filed a suit on October 12, 1950

facts.text: Raghavamma filed suit on October 12, 1950 in Subordinate Judge, Bapatla for possession.

anchor.surface_text: Raghavamma filed a suit on October 12, 1950 in the Court of the Subordinate judge, Bapatlal, for possession of the plaint scheduled properties

facts.text: Subordinate Judge, Bapatla dismissed the suit.

anchor.surface_text: the Subordinate judge, Bapatla, dismissing the suit filed by the appellants for possession of the plaint schedule properties.

facts.text: Andhra High Court affirmed findings of Subordinate Judge on adoption and partition, dismissed appeal.

anchor.surface_text: High Court of Andhra confirming those of the Subordinate judge, Bapatla, dismissing the suit filed by the appellants

facts.text: First defendant denied adoption of Venkayya by Pitchayya.

anchor.surface_text: The first defendant denied that Venkayya was given in adoption to Pitchayya or that there was a partition

facts.text: First defendant claimed Chimpirayya died undivided from grandson Subbarao.

anchor.surface_text: She averred that Chimpirayya died undivided from his grandson Subbarao and, therefore, Subbarao became entitled

facts.text: Subordinate Judge found no proof of adoption of Venkayya by Pitchayya.

anchor.surface_text: the plaintiff had not established the factum of adoption of Venkayya by her husband Pitchayya

facts.text: Subordinate Judge found no proof of division between Chimpirayya and Pitchayya.

anchor.surface_text: and that she also failed to prove that Chimpirayya and Pitchayya were divided from each other

facts.text: Supreme Court affirmed concurrent findings that there was no adoption.

anchor.surface_text: we cannot say that the finding was vitiated by such errors that we should review the entire evidence

facts.text: Supreme Court affirmed no partition between Chimpirayya and Pitchayya.

anchor.surface_text: both the Courts below found that there was no partition between Chimpirayya and Pitchayya

facts.text: Chenchamma did not know of the will until after suit filed.

anchor.surface_text: she came to know of the Will only after the suit was filed.

facts.text: High Court certificate granted under Article 133(1) for appeal to Supreme Court.

facts.text: Supreme Court rejected preliminary objection on scope of certificate.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, reject this preliminary objection.

facts.text: Supreme Court declined to interfere with concurrent findings on adoption and partition.

issues.text: Whether a will executed by a member of a joint Hindu family would of itself be operative to effect a severance between him and the other members of the family by reason of the disposition contained in the will

anchor.surface_text: the affirming decree appealed from involves the following substantial questions of law - Whether a will executed by a member of a joint Hindu family would of itself be operative to effect a severance between him and the other members of the family by reason of the disposition contained in the will.

holdings.text: The terms of the certificate under Article 133(1) do not circumscribe the scope of the appeal to the Supreme Court; once granted, the Court can review facts and law fully.

anchor.surface_text: Article 133(1) of the Constitution. The material part of Article 133(1) reads An appeal shall lie to the Supreme Court from any judgment,... But the terms of the certificate do not circumscribe the scope of the appeal

holdings.reasoning_summary: Certificate is precondition for maintainability but does not limit review powers; distinguishes from Art 136.

holdings.text: There are no exceptional circumstances warranting interference with the concurrent findings of fact that there was no adoption of Venkayya by Pitchayya.

anchor.surface_text: both the Courts below gave concurrent findings of fact on the question of adoption as well as on partition and this Court will not reconsider the evidence as a rule of practice and there are no exceptional circumstances

holdings.reasoning_summary: Long-standing practice not to interfere with concurrent findings absent shock to conscience, natural justice violation, or grave injustice; evidence appreciation not exceptional.

holdings.text: There are no exceptional circumstances warranting interference with the concurrent findings of fact that there was no partition between Chimpirayya and Pitchayya.

anchor.surface_text: both the Courts below gave concurrent findings of fact on the question of adoption as well as on partition and this Court will not reconsider the evidence as a rule of practice and there are no exceptional circumstances

holdings.reasoning_summary: Same practice as above; ample evidence supports findings, no legal errors; presumption of jointness applies.

holdings.text: A will executed by a member of a joint Hindu family does not of itself effect severance in status unless the intention to separate is communicated to the knowledge of the other coparceners before death.

anchor.surface_text: So, the important question that arises is whether the testator in the present case became separated from the joint family before his death. ... the knowledge of the members of the family of the manifested intention

holdings.reasoning_summary: Will speaks from death; undivided interest survives; requires knowledge for severance per Hindu texts and precedents.

holdings.text: Severance in status requires an unequivocal declaration of intention to separate brought to the knowledge of the other affected coparceners; uncommunicated intention is ineffective.

anchor.surface_text: The main question of law that arises is whether a member of a joint Hindu family becomes separated from the other members of the family by a mere declaration of his unequivocal intention to divide from the family without bringing the same to the knowledge

holdings.reasoning_summary: Derived from Hindu law texts (Yajnavalkya, Mitakshara etc.) and Privy Council decisions; declaration must be manifested to affected parties.

holdings.text: Chimpirayya did not become separated from the joint family before his death as there was no communicated intention to separate.

anchor.surface_text: The general principle undoubtedly is that a Hindu family is presumed to be joint unless the contrary is proved... So, the important question that arises is whether the testator in the present case became separated from the joint family before his death.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No prior partition or declaration; will's recitals insufficient without communication; presumption of jointness.

holdings.text: The date of severance relates back to the date of declaration of intention upon acquisition of knowledge by coparceners, but does not affect vested rights acquired in the intervening period.

anchor.surface_text: The doctrine of relation back has already been recognised by Hindu Law as developed by Courts ... though the date of severance is that of manifestation of the intention to separate, the rights accrued to others in the joint family property between the said manifestation and the knowledge

holdings.reasoning_summary: Evolves equitable limitation by analogy to adoption doctrine and general retroactivity principles to avoid disturbing vested rights; open to SC to develop.
